title: The Harvard Crimson is right to stand by journalistic principles
text:
In September, the organization, Act on a Dream, held a rally calling for abolition of the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency (ICE). Crimson reporters called ICE for comment (ICE did not respond). According to an online petition circulated by Act on a Dream, this standard reportorial practice showed “cultural insensitivity” to ICE’s record of “surveilling and retaliating against” activists. “In this political climate, a request for comment is virtually the same as tipping them off,” the petition claimed. For what it’s worth, Crimson editors have averred convincingly that they did not try to contact ICE until after the rally had ended, and would have provided no information about specific attendees, if ICE had granted the paper’s request for an interview. Some 700 people (and about a dozen student organizations, including Harvard College Democrats) have endorsed this petition, with its demand that the paper apologize and change the policy that required it to call ICE for comment. Meanwhile, Act on a Dream and others are refusing contact with Crimson reporters.

That’s about 700 people, many and perhaps most of them students at the country’s most prestigious university, who have understandable concerns about ICE surveillance, deportations, and the historical treatment of immigrants and other minority groups by the press — but a warped view of how legitimate, ethical media work. Every responsible news gatherer seeks comment from the named subjects of its coverage; none would accept the self-censorship the petition demands of the Crimson. This is what it means to be an honest broker of information, “without fear or favor.” Without organizations willing to take on that sometimes-thankless role, public discussion degenerates into a struggle between competing brands of propaganda. (We emailed a request to Act on a Dream to hear its side of the story, and have not received a reply.)

AD

AD

Mr. Trump does not get that; we expect more from the next generation’s best and brightest. And indeed, there is cause for hope in this episode. The Crimson’s admirable reaction has been to meet with critics, listen to their concerns — but stick to principle. “At stake here, we believe, is one of the core tenets that defines America’s free and independent press,” two top editors, seniors Angela N. Fu and Kristine E. Guillaume, wrote, “the right — and prerogative — of reporters to contact any person or organization relevant to a story. . . . This ensures the article is as thorough, balanced, and unbiased toward any particular viewpoint as possible. A world where news outlets categorically refuse to contact certain kinds of sources — a world where news outlets let third-party groups dictate the terms of their coverage — is a less informed, less accurate, and ultimately less democratic world.” We couldn’t have said it better ourselves.
